question: Endemicity of a disease means:
exp: Endemic Is the constant presence of a disease agent in a defined geographical area; refers to 'usual or expected frequency' of a disease in a population. For instance, common cold is endemic because somebody always has one. Endemic diseases in India are: Measles, mumps, rubella, chicken pox, peussis, TB, HIV, Cancers, diabetes, hypertension etc. Epidemics can arise from uncontrolled endemics also.
opa: Occurs clearly in excess of normal expectancy
opb: Is constantly present in a population

question: Food poisoning is an example of:
exp: 1. Point source epidemic ( single exposure ) Sudden rise sudden fall. Cluster of cases in single IP. All cases develop within one incubation period of the disease E. g. Food poisoning, Bhopal gas tragedy. 2. Common source, continuous or repeated exposure epidemics Sharp rise Fall is interrupted by secondary peaks Eg. Contaminated well in a village, Water Borne Cholera. 3. Propagated source epidemic Gradual rise & gradual fall over long time. Person to person transmission E. g:- HEP. A, POLIO.

question: A community in sub-African area has a weekly repo of 50-60 malarial cases, all in children. No adult case has been repoed. This week count of cases is 55. What kind of disease it would be classified as?
exp: The above given case is an example of endemic disease as the no. of cases are still between the usually expected cases in an area and as only children are affected it is a holoendemic disease. Hyperendemic disease Refers to endemic disease affecting all age groups. It would have been labelled as epidemic if the no. of cases show an abrupt increase than expected cases in an area.

question: First step in investigation of an epidemic is:-
exp: Investigation of an epidemic-chronological steps: 1) Verification of diagnosis - 1st step2) Confirmation of existence of epidemic 3) Defining population at risk 4) Rapid search of all cases and their characteristics 5) Data analysis 6) Formation of hypothesis 7) Testing of hypothesis 8) Evaluation of ecological factor 9) Fuher investigation of population at risk 10) Writing the repo

question: A primary health center (PHC) repos 40-50 cases in a week in the community. This week there are 48 cases normally, based on previous records. This is called
exp: Endemic: constant presence of a disease or infectious agent within a given geographic area or population group without impoation from outside. (i. e. the disease is occurring at the usual or expected frequency) e. g.: common cold Sporadic: irregularly scattered cases which have no connection with each other. E. g.: tetanus. Epidemic: Occurrence of the disease in a community or region clearly in excess of normal expectancy in a given time period. Outbreak: Outbreak carries the same definition of epidemic, but is often used for a more limited geographic area.

question: The area is declared free of epidemic:
exp: Epidemic: Number of cases of a disease clearly in excess of normal frequency. An area is declared free of epidemic; if on search, no new cases are repoed for 'twice the incubation period of the disease since the occurrence of last case'.
opb: No new case repoed for the incubation period of disease since the last case
opc: No new case repoed for twice the incubation period of disease since the last case
opd: No new case repoed for six months since the last case
